results.headline: New in Los Angeles, and Willing to Do Anything for Money
results.summary_short: “Going Down in La-La Land” is a familiar enough story of a young and beautiful person hoping to make it big in Hollywood only to attain disillusionment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Going Down in LA-LA Land

results.headline: If They Can Make It in New York City …
results.summary_short: Downtown Express,” a first feature from the documentarian David Grubin, radiates so much love for its tunes and location that it’s difficult to grouch.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Downtown Express

results.headline: When Dog Disappears, the Humans Seem Lost
results.summary_short: In “Darling Companion” a rescued mutt named Freeway bounds off into the woods of Colorado, and impressive noncanine cast members search for him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Darling Companion

results.headline: Chimps Eat, Scratch, Groom
results.summary_short: “Chimpanzee” follows Oscar, who is orphaned and then adopted by an alpha male, in this latest piece of gorgeously shot pablum from Disneynature.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chimpanzee

results.headline: A Sketch Artist Animates a Fraternity of Bumblers
results.summary_short: “Oki’s Movie,” in four parts, explores film school and romance from the points of view of three characters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oki's Movie

results.headline: The Good Life With Bad Choices
results.summary_short: The documentary “Unraveled” follows Marc Dreier, a lawyer convicted of defrauding investors through elaborate schemes, in the days before his sentencing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unraveled

results.headline: Wry and Subtle Jesting? Not Here, Knucklehead
results.summary_short: “The Three Stooges” is Peter and Bobby Farrelly’s paean to Moe, Larry and Curly and the art of the eye poke.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Three Stooges

results.headline: When the Best Teacher Doesn’t Have a Degree
results.summary_short: In “Monsieur Lazhar,” nominated for a best foreign language Oscar, an Algerian immigrant with no teaching experience wins over a class of traumatized sixth graders.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monsieur Lazhar

results.headline: Loving, and Maybe Exploiting, Armenia
results.summary_short: In “Here,” a satellite-mapping engineer and a photographer join forces amid the beauty of rural Armenia but find the goals of their work are at odds.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Here

results.headline: Taking a Chain Saw to Horror Movie Clichés
results.summary_short: “The Cabin in the Woods” is a slasher/zombie/monster film with a bloody but winking twist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Cabin in the Woods

results.headline: Single Motherhood, Sitcom Style
results.summary_short: “L!fe Happens,” a film about an unplanned baby born to a young woman (Krysten Ritter) with two female roommates, is a sister to similar comedies on TV.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life Happens

results.headline: Age, They Hope, Won’t Wither Them ... Quite Yet
results.summary_short: “Late Bloomers,” starring William Hurt and Isabella Rossellini, is a romantic comedy about a married couple dealing with the indignities of aging.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Late Bloomers

results.headline: Club Kids of Today Party With Their Predecessors
results.summary_short: The journalists of Entrisme in France meet up with Yves Adrien, a popular-music critic from the old days, in “Kids of Today.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kids of Today

results.headline: Musicians, Their Care and Feeding
results.summary_short: “How to Grow a Band” is the story of the fusion quintet the Punch Brothers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How To Grow A Band

results.headline: In Hole, Then Scrambling Out of One
results.summary_short: “Hit So Hard” is a documentary about the fast and brutal times of Patty Schemel, the drummer for the band Hole.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hit So Hard

results.headline: Flexing His Way Through a Borrowed Plot
results.summary_short: In “Lockout” Guy Pearce plays a soldier who must rescue the president’s daughter from kidnappers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lockout

results.headline: Horror, Comedy, Time Travel and Teenagers
results.summary_short: Joseph Kahn brings together that classic cinematic pair, murder and prom night, as the underpinning for “Detention.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Detention

results.headline: A Hate Crime, Solved Years Later
results.summary_short: A real case is dressed up as fiction in “Deadline,” a film about the killing of a young African-American man.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deadline

results.headline: A Mecca for Mere Mortals Devoted to Superpowers
results.summary_short: In the documentary “Comic-Con Episode IV: A Fan’s Hope,” Morgan Spurlock surveys the major convention for avid followers of comic books, superheroes and video games.
results.display_title: Comic-Con Episode Four: A Fan's Hope

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Comic-Con Episode Four: A Fan's Hope

results.headline: The Bible Belt Goes to College
results.summary_short: A Baptist boy from Texas goes to a Northwestern liberal arts college in “Blue Like Jazz,” an adaptation of Don Miller’s memoir.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blue Like Jazz
